Legislative History of Laws

For legislative history of D.C. Law 12-98, see Historical and Statutory Notes following § 9-1215.01.

Law 15-51, the "Make a Difference Amendment Act of 2003", was introduced in Council and assigned Bill No. 15-71, which was referred to the Committee of the Whole. The Bill was adopted on first and second readings on July 8, 2003, and September 16, 2003, respectively. Signed by the Mayor on October 6, 2003, it was assigned Act No. 15-164 and transmitted to both Houses of Congress for its review. D.C. Law 15-51 became effective on December 9, 2003.

sections.text: No person shall be selected by the Commission to be honored unless that person meets the following criteria:

The person's contribution must have been made in the public interest, must have materially improved American society, or the environment and must have had a positive effect on a significant number of people in the United States.
The person must have been acting as a private citizen and not as an appointed or elected government official for the acts for which the person is to be recognized.
The person must have undertaken the achievement for which the person is to be recognized outside of his or her normal work assignment, and not for profit.
The person must have been born in the United States or naturalized as a United States citizen.
No person shall be selected for recognition until a minimum of 5 years after the achievement for which the individual is being nominated has elapsed.
The Committee shall not consider the race, color, religion, national origin, sex, or political affiliation of any nominee in making its decision on whether to honor an individual's accomplishments.

There shall be no limit on the number of annual nominees that the Committee may consider for recognition. However, no more than 25 persons may be selected for recognition with a marker in any calendar year.
A nominee must receive a two-thirds majority vote of the Committee members present and voting at a meeting of the Committee.

Nominees approved by the Committee shall be submitted to the Mayor. The Mayor shall transmit the names of nominees by resolution to the Council for a 30-day period of review, excluding Saturdays, Sundays, legal holidays and days of Council recess. If the Council does not approve or disapprove the nominees, in whole or in part, by resolution within this 30-day review period, the nominees shall be deemed disapproved.
